<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>

char *UtSprintf(const char *Spec, ...)
{
    va_list                     Args;
    static UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t Buf[UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS];
    static uint32               TextIndex = 0;

    ++TextIndex;
    if (TextIndex >= UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS)
        TextIndex = 0;

    va_start(Args, Spec);
    vsnprintf(Buf[TextIndex].Text, sizeof(Buf[TextIndex].Text), Spec, Args);
    va_end(Args);

    return Buf[TextIndex].Text;
}

explanation:
Rule 14.2 applies specifically to the structure and contents of for statements. The provided function contains no for statement, so there are no code fragments relevant to this rule to investigate. Specific fragments and why they are not applicable to Rule 14.2:
- "static UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t Buf[...]" and "static uint32 TextIndex = 0;": declarations only, not for loops.
- "++TextIndex; if (TextIndex >= UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS) TextIndex = 0;": an increment and conditional wrap-around, but not a for statement; Rule 14.2 concerns the three clauses of for loops only.
- "va_start(Args, Spec); vsnprintf(..., Args); va_end(Args);": variadic argument handling and function calls, not for loops.
- "return Buf[TextIndex].Text;": return statement, not a for loop.

While other MISRA rules might be relevant (thread-safety of static data, use of variadic functions, bounds-checking of vsnprintf, etc.), none of these fragments fall under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2, so no further investigation is required for this rule.
